[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/secp256k1_ecdsa.rs] [Feature: test] [Test-only functions] Are there other test-only functions beyond sign_arbitrary_message() that could be exploited if test features leak into production builds, bypassing critical security checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/secp256k1_ecdsa.rs] [Trait: SigningKey] [Message domain separation] Does the sign<T: CryptoHash>() implementation at lines 88-96 provide proper domain separation between different message types T, or can attackers sign one type and verify as another? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/secp256k1_ecdsa.rs] [Trait: VerifyingKey] [Type safety] Does the VerifyingKey trait at lines 193-196 enforce type safety between SigningKeyMaterial and SignatureMaterial, or can type confusion enable signature verification with wrong key types? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/secp256k1_ecdsa.rs] [Trait: Signature] [Verify generic] The verify<T: CryptoHash>() method at line 267 accepts any CryptoHash type - can this enable signature reuse across different transaction types or protocol messages? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/secp256k1_ecdsa.rs] [Trait: Uniform] [Distribution uniformity] Does the Uniform trait implementation for PrivateKey at lines 104-117 produce truly uniform key distribution, or does rejection sampling introduce statistical bias? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/secp256k1_ecdsa.rs] [Function: sign()] [Serialization error] If traits::signing_message() fails at line 92, does the SerializationError properly propagate without leaking the message content or private key information? (Low)
